p.text: A warrant for the arrest or detention under this Part of a contemnor shall be addressed to the Sheriff and may be issued under the hand of the Judge or officer presiding in the Court directing the arrest or detention.

The warrant must state the nature of the contempt and the reason for the committal: Ferraro v Woodward (1978) 143 CLR 102; 19 ALR 188 . The form of warrant was Form 65, and the warrant for committal was Form 66 in the pre UCP versions of the approved forms.
Where the contemnor is not a corporation, the Court may punish contempt by committal to a correctional centre or fine or both.
[subr (1) am Amendment 308: Gaz 20 of 21 February 1997 p 828]
Where the contemnor is a corporation, the Court may punish contempt by sequestration or fine or both.

The Court may make an order for punishment on terms, including a suspension of punishment or a suspension of punishment in case the contemnor gives security in such manner and in such sum as the Court may approve for good behaviour and performs the terms of the security.
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 55.13.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 40.6.

Apart from the distinction between civil and criminal contempt, a distinction is also sometimes made between “technical contempt” on the one hand, and wilful or contumacious contempt, on the other. The essential purpose of the distinction is to differentiate between conduct which, though constituting contempt, does not justify any punitive sanction, and conduct which does: Attorney-General v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1980] 1 NSWLR 362 at 367 . In drawing that distinction the contemnor’s intention is a relevant: Bell v Stewart (1920) 28 CLR 419 at 429–32; 27 ALR 1 ; but not necessarily determinative consideration: Harkianakis v Skalkos (No 2) (NSWSC, Mason P, Powell and Beazley JJA, No 40514/96, 15 October 1997, unreported, BC9705162) at [3]. There are many occasions where punitive sanctions are inappropriate and the contempt is properly to be regarded as technical: Shoppe v Nathan & Co [1892] 1 QB 245 (clerical error leading to a demand for overpayment of judgment amount); Australian Consolidated Press Ltd v Morgan (1965) 112 CLR 483; [1966] ALR 387; BC6500220 (misinterpretation of undertaking). Apart from instances of this kind, in cases of civil contempt the court is primarily concerned with remedying the error or non-compliance. Consequently, the contempt can be waived by the opposing party taking a step in the action: Roberts v Albert Bridge Co (1873) LR 8 Ch App 753. Alternatively, provided the alleged contemnor has taken appropriate remedial action, the court may merely accept an apology and order the costs of the enforcement proceedings against the contemnor: Commissioner for Fair Trading v Youngdown Pty Ltd [2003] NSWSC 646; BC200303949 ; or, indeed, make no order as to costs: Adam Phones Ltd v Goldschmidt [1999] 4 All ER 486 ; Australian Consolidated Press Ltd v Morgan , above, CLR at 492; also see generally the court's powers under UCPR r 40.6 .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.13.2] Wilful conduct and contumacious contempt

p.text: The distinction between wilful and contumacious contempt “cannot always be sharply drawn”: Australian Consolidated Press Ltd v Morgan (1965) 112 CLR 483 at 501; [1966] ALR 387; BC6500220 . The essential element in the distinction is that contumacious contempt involves both intentional conduct and knowing defiance of the court's order and authority. Not every intentional disobedience will involve such an element: Australian Consolidated Press Ltd v Morgan , above (disobedience to ambiguous undertaking); Trade Practices Commission v CG Smith Pty Ltd (1978) 30 FLR 368; (1978) ATPR ¶40-059 and see Fairclough & Sons v Manchester Ship Canal Co (No 2) [1897] WN 7 ; Worthington v Ad-Lib Club Ltd [1965] Ch 236; [1964] 3 All ER 674 ; Steiner Products Ltd v Willy Steiner Ltd [1966] 2 All ER 387; [1966] 1 WLR 986 and Re Mileage Conference Group of Tyre Manufacturers [1966] 2 All ER 849; [1966] 1 WLR 1137 . In the case of merely wilful civil contempt, the court’s essential purpose will be to ensure future compliance with the court's order. In the case of contumacious contempt, the party concerned having already evidenced their knowing defiance, the court will be concerned both to enforce future compliance and also to sanction the past defiance.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.13.3] Burden of proof in contempt proceedings

heading.title: Burden of proof in contempt proceedings

p.text: The moving party bears the onus of establishing the contempt charge beyond reasonable doubt, irrespective of whether the alleged contempt is civil or criminal: Witham v Holloway (1995) 183 CLR 525 at 550; 131 ALR 401; [1995] HCA 3; BC9506443 . The essentially punitive nature of the proceedings will usually require careful observance of the ordinary evidentiary and procedural rules: Spindler v Balog (1959) 76 WN (NSW) 391 ; McLeod v Henty (1900) 25 VLR 648 ; Taylor v Whelan [1962] VR 306 ; unless the respondent agrees to waive the strict rules of evidence: Maslen v Official Receiver (1947) 74 CLR 602; [1947] ALR 489 .

The party charged with contempt cannot be compelled to give evidence, or answer interrogatories, contrary to the privilege against self incrimination: Comet Products UK Ltd v Hawkex Plastics Ltd [1971] 2 QB 67; [1971] 1 All ER 1141 in which the court considered that a deponent should not be cross-examined on his or her affidavit.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.13.5] Applications by parties in contempt

p.text: There is a general rule that a party in contempt is not entitled to be heard on any matter arising in the same proceedings — save for an appeal against the contempt finding itself: see X Ltd v Morgan-Grampian (Publishers) Ltd [1991] 1 AC 1 at 47; [1990] 2 All ER 1 ; Hadkinson v Hadkinson [1952] P 285; [1952] 2 All ER 567 ; and the judgment of Hutley JA in Permewan Wright Consolidated Pty Ltd v A-G (NSW); Ex rel Franklins Stores Pty Ltd (1978) 35 NSWLR 365 . The rule applies not only to persons against whom a contempt finding has been made, but also to situations where the court is clearly satisfied that an allegation of contempt is likely to be made out: Young v Jackman (1986) 7 NSWLR 97 ; cf Howse Fink & Johnson Computing Services Pty Ltd v Beard (NSWSC, Powell J, No 1841/89, 26 October 1989, unreported, BC8901536). Despite views to the contrary: see Young v Jackman , above; the balance of authority favours the view that the rule is discretionary, rather than constituting an absolute impediments to applications by a contemnor: Borrie and Lowe, The Law of Contempt, 3rd ed, Butterworths, London, 1996, pp 6451–53. Consequently, in addition to the ability of a contemnor to appeal (against the contempt finding itself) the court retains an overall discretion to deal with any application by a contemnor, where it is satisfied that it is necessary to do so: X Ltd v Morgan-Grampian (Publishers) Ltd , above, AC at 47; In the Marriage of Fahmi & Fahmi (1995) 19 Fam LR 517; 121 FLR 210 ; KP Cable Investments Pty Ltd v Meltglow Pty Ltd (1995) 56 FCR 189; 13 ACLC 437 ; Woollahra Municipal Council v Dalip Shahani (1990) 69 LGRA 435; BC9003026 .
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 55.13.6] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 101(5), s 101(6), s 101A, s 75A.

Appeals lie to the Court of Appeal in matters involving both criminal and civil contempt, and irrespective of whether or not the contempt occurred during the course of either criminal or civil proceedings: Smith v R (1991) 25 NSWLR 1 ; Fraser v R (No 2) (1985) 1 NSWLR 680 ; Witham v Holloway (1995) 183 CLR 525 at 550; 131 ALR 401; [1995] HCA 3; BC9506443 ; and see s 101(5) of the Supreme Court Act 1970. Under s 75A , the Court of Appeal may allow the appeal and remit the proceedings back to the division of the court for further hearing or re-hearing: Witham v Holloway , above, CLR at 549–50.

No appeal lies from an acquittal of a charge of criminal contempt: Director of Public Prosecutions v Chidiac (1991) 25 NSWLR 372 ; Wentworth v Rares (No 2) (NSWCA, Full Court, 13 December 1990, unreported, BC9001618); Markisic v Commonwealth [2006] NSWCA 150; BC200604474 ; see SCA s 101(6) . An appeal does lie from an acquittal on a charge of civil contempt: Street v Hearne (2007) 70 NSWLR 231; 2007] NSWCA 113; BC200706638 ; affirmed Hearne v Street (2008) 235 CLR 125; 248 ALR 609; [2008] HCA 36; BC200806976 . A question of law arising concerning criminal contempt may be referred to the Court of Appeal under s 101A of the Supreme Court Act 1970: Attorney-General (NSW) v X (2000) 49 NSWLR 653; [2000] NSWCA 199; BC200004289 .

Where contempt is established on an application by a private prosecutor, the usual order is for costs to be paid on the ordinary basis: McIntyre v Perkes (1988) 15 NSWLR 417; BC8801160 ; Ditfort v Katz (NSWCA, Full Court, 8 July 1991, unreported, BC9101811); Global Custodians Ltd v Mesh [2000] NSWSC 845; BC200005019 at [37] per Young CJ in Eq (no such apology proffered, restraining order made and costs on usual basis). But costs may be a consideration in the imposition of a penalty and, at least in that context, costs may be ordered to be paid on an indemnity basis: Farahbakht v Midas Australia Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1322; BC200610117 at [58] per Brereton J; NCR Australia Pty Ltd v Credit Connection Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 1118; BC200509669 at [102] per Campbell J (full indemnity for costs); McGuirk v University of New South Wales [2010] NSWSC 448; BC201003075 (order for costs of the penalty proceedings to be paid forthwith on an indemnity basis); Circuit Finance Australia v Sobbi [2010] NSWSC 912; BC201005901 (order for costs alone not sufficient —– conduct was deliberate and contrition too late and too little —– fine ordered and indemnity costs).

The law of contempt does not apply to the acts of superior court judges whether those acts are judicial or ministerial in nature: Yeldham v Rajski (1989) 18 NSWLR 48; 45 A Crim R 1 , (alleged defamatory remarks and refusal of leave to prosecute a witness for perjury).

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.13.9] Contempt by the exercise of a statutory power

heading.title: Contempt by the exercise of a statutory power

p.text: The law of contempt may apply to the exercise of a statutory power unless the power is conferred in terms that expressly authorise the doing of the act that is alleged to constitute the contempt: Pioneer Concrete (Vic) Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1982) 152 CLR 460; 43 ALR 449 ; Victoria v Australian Building Construction Employees' and Builders' Labourers' Federation (1982) 152 CLR 25; 41 ALR 71 ; Attorney-General (NSW) v Ray (No 3) (1989) 90 ALR 263; 99 FLR 265 .
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 55.13.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Bail Act 1978 s 64.
(NSW) Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act 1999.

A conviction of criminal contempt of court is punishable according to the same principles that apply to the sentencing function for ordinary criminal offences: NCR Australia Pty Ltd v Credit Connection Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 1118; BC200509669 at [24] . Because it is a common law offence there is no maximum penalty: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 2) , above, at 314; R v Dunbabin; Ex parte Williams (1935) 53 CLR 434 at 442; [1935] ALR 232; (1935) 9 ALJR 74; BC3500041 . The common law power to grant bail is preserved by Bail Act 1978 s 64 ; cf Young v Registrar, Court of Appeal (No 2) (1993) 71 A Crim R 121; BC9300038 . But the writ of habeas corpus cannot be invoked to challenge the detention of a contemnor: Young v Registrar, Court of Appeal (No 3) (1993) 32 NSWLR 262; BC9303898 .

The Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act 1999 applies to a sentence for criminal contempt of court: Director-General, Dept of Fair Trading v Yang (2002) 132 A Crim R 438; [2002] NSWSC 754; BC200204854 ; Attorney-General (NSW) v Whiley (1993) 31 NSWLR 314; [1993] NSWJB 74 . The court’s powers are not restricted to the alternatives (suggested by SCR 55.13) of custodial detention or fine. The court retains the flexibility to impose a sanction appropriate to the particular circumstances: Registrar of the Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 2) (1992) 26 NSWLR 309 at 319A–D and 320G a punishment that is not constrained by the express terms of SCR 55.13. Relevant considerations include the normative role of the punishment and general deterrence: Registrar of the Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 2) (1992) 26 NSWLR 309 at 314 .

In principle, a contempt of court could be punished by anything within the range of penalties that can be imposed for a crime, pursuant to the Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act 1999 , including imprisonment, periodic detention, home detention, community service orders, good behaviour bonds, dismissal of the charge accompanied by either a good behaviour bond or a condition that the offender participate in an intervention programme, deferral of sentence, suspended sentence, fine, or the making of a non-association or a place restriction order: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 2) , above, at 319; NCR Australia Pty Ltd v Credit Connection Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 1118; BC200509669 at [25] per Campbell J (deliberate breach of Mareva order on ten occasions — community service order made); see also Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) v Michalik (2004) 52 ACSR 115; 23 ACLC 188; [2004] NSWSC 1259; BC200409027 , Palmer J (breach of asset preservation orders — imprisonment for 18 months and fines ordered); Ronowska v Kus (No 2) [2012] NSWSC 817; BC201205605 , Pembroke J at [51]–[60] (deliberate breach of order for payment — dishonest evidence — deliberate evasion of service — imprisonment for 18 months).

The Crown is immune from criminal proceedings, including criminal contempt proceedings: Arnold v Minister Administering the Water Management Act 2000 (No 3) (2009) 165 LGERA 329; [2009] NSWLEC 56; BC200903161 at [21]–[36] (allegation of improper pressure being applied to a litigant to withdraw from proceedings by withholding of ex gratia payments — contempt proceedings against Commonwealth dismissed); In re M [1994] 1 AC 377; [1993] 1 All ER 537 ; Crowther v Queensland [2007] 1 Qd R 232; [2006] QCA 308; BC200606585 at [14]–[27] .

Sequestration does not deprive a corporation of property. On discharge of the sequestration order, all the property must be returned, less any fine and costs that may have been imposed: Australian Consolidated Press Ltd v Morgan (1965) 112 CLR 483 at 501; [1966] ALR 387; BC6500220 .

Normally the contemnor is present. However, in exceptional cases the court may proceed to sentence a contemnor, even to the extent of imposing a term of imprisonment, in their absence. The power to do so should only be exercised in exceptional circumstances — which will typically involve satisfaction that the contemnor knowingly contravened the judgment or order, has been deliberately avoiding service and intentionally failing to contest the proceedings: Ronowska v Kus (No 2) [2012] NSWSC 817; BC201205605 , Pembroke J at [51]–[60] (conduct of the contemnor amounted to a voluntary waiver of his right to be present) citing R v Jones (1998) 72 SASR 281 at 297; 104 A Crim R 399; [1998] SASC 7021; BC9806980 .
Where a contemnor is committed to a correctional centre for a term, the Court may order his discharge before the expiry of the term.
[r 14 am Amendment 308: Gaz 20 of 21 February 1997 p 828]

This power will normally be exercised only where there has been some change in circumstances since the sentence was imposed: Young v Registrar, Court of Appeal (No 3) (1993) 32 NSWLR 262 . For example, where the contemnor has purged his or her contempt (Crowley v Brown [1964] 1 WLR 147 ; Ball v Etches (1817) 1 Russ & M 324; 39 ER 125; Gray v Campbell (1830) Rus & M 323; 39 ER 124); where no good purpose will be served by further detaining the contemnor (Re Barrell Enterprises [1972] 3 All ER 631; [1973] 1 WLR 19 ); where the proceedings were voidable for irregularity (Levi v Ward (1823) 1 Sim & St 334; 57 ER 134); or where the contemnor could show he or she enjoyed a legal privilege from arrest or committal: R v Stubbs (1790) 3 TR 735; 100 ER 830.
[r 15 rep Amendment 85: Gaz 46 of 28 April 1978 p 1566]
